coredata.dc:title: Observation of X-ray resonant Raman spectra and transition to resonant fluorescence
coredata.dc:creator: Udagawa, Yasuo
Tohji, Kazuyuki
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The first observation of X-ray Raman spectra of transition metal compounds is reported on copper, cuprous oxide, and cupric oxide in resonant, pre-resonant as well as non-resonant conditions. In the non-resonant condition the spectra are, unlike fluorescence X-ray, characteristic of each compound. Upon approaching the resonant condition a smooth and continuous transition from Raman spectra to K fluorescence doublet of copper is observed. The excitation energy dependence of the spectra can be reproduced quite well by a simple calculation employing second-order perturbation theory.

Introduction Inelastic X-ray scattering called X-ray Raman scattering has been intermittently studied by var- ious authors for the past three decades [1 15]. It is distinctly different from Compton scattering in that the energy loss experienced by the X-ray photon is the difference between two energy levels of the ma- terial and is independent of the scattering angle. Compared with the well-known counterpart in the optical region, however, only little is known about X-ray Raman spectra. The coupling of the electrons to the photon is de- scribed by the semiclassical Hamiltonian H= (e/mc)pA+ (e2/2mc2)A2. It has been established that the scattering (by sec- ond-order perturbation) by the first term of eq. (1) is responsible for optical Raman scattering. In the X- ray region two kinds of Raman scattering have been reported. One is the scattering from light elements like car- bon and is associated with the promotion of K elec- trons to the continuum. Mizuno and Ohmura E 2] pointed out theoretically that this comes from first- order perturbation of the second term in eq. (1) and that the spectra should be similar to absorption. After a series of works by Suzuki [3 5] there are several reports on the spectra of graphite [12,13], and re- Volume 148, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETrERS 8 July 1988 chromator a whole spectrum was not obtained, even in the resonant condition. The aim of the present study is to obtain X-ray Raman spectra of transition metal compounds un- der higher resolution in order to fully understand the phenomenon and also to examine whether the X-ray Raman spectra contain information on absorption edge or extended fine structure which can be utilized for the study of electronic as well as geometrical structure of materials. In this paper X-ray Raman spectra of copper metal, cupric oxide (CuO ) and eu- prous oxide (Cu20) are reported in the resonant, pre- resonant, and non-resonant conditions for the first time. Each compound has its characteristic spectrum in the non-resonant condition. By approaching res- onance to K absorption, the spectra gradually change to that of the K fluorescence spectrum of copper, which is characteristic of the element and does not depend on compounds. The excitation energy de- pendence of the spectra is nicely reproduced by a cal- culation using simple perturbation theory. 2. Experimental The measurement was carried out at beam line BL- 1 OC of the Photon Factory at the National Labora- tory for High Energy Physics (KEK). The experi- mental conditions are similar to those described previously [15]. In short, the X-ray beam from the ring with current of 150 300 mA is monochroma- tized by a double crystral Si (111) monochromator with a resolution better than 2 eV and is focused to about I mmx 5 mm in size by a double focusing mir- ror. The scattered X-rays from the sample which is placed at the focus were dispersed by a Johansson- type ground and bent Ge( 333) crystal and detected by a position-sensitive proportional counter (PSPC). The centers of the sample, the crystal, and the PSPC are in a plane which is perpendicular to the polari- zation vector of the incident X-rays, e1. In a separate experiment the dispersing crystal and the PSPC were rotated by 900 in order that the polarization vector of the scattered light, e2, is perpendicular to e~. The energy of the scattered X-ray was calibrated by the K flu- orescence from copper. 3. Results Figs. 2 4 show Raman spectra of Cu, CuO and Cu20 excited by X-rays from 8958 to 8988 eV. The spectra excited by X-rays with higher energy than 8988 eV and those with X-rays lower than 8958 eV are almost the same as those by 8988 and 8958 eV excitation, respectively. In the off-resonant condition, a sharp edge is ob- served to the higher energy side for each compound, and the energy differences between the edge and the exciting light correspond to L1~1 absorption energy of copper (935 eV). The detailed structure is, however, not the same in the three compounds, reflecting the 102 Volume 148, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 July 1988 difference in the electronic structure of each com- pound. The spectrum of metallic copper consists of a sharp edge and a rather broad peak, and resembles that of Cu20. In the spectrum of CuO two peaks sep- arated by 20 eV, which corresponds to the energy difference of L11 and L111 levels, are clearly resolved. No other fine structure is, however, observed. Upon approaching the resonant condition the spectra show remarkable changes. When excited by X-rays above 8988 eV, the same spectrum, namely the well-known Ka doublet of copper atom, is ob- served for all the compounds studied. With detuning the excitation energy, the scattering intensity de- creases drastically, and the shape of the two com- ponents of the doublet becomes more and more asymmetric, having a tail to the lower energy side. Peak energies shift toward lower energy in accord- ance with the decrease in excitation energy. The change starts at higher excitation energy in CuO, re- flecting that the energy of the absorption threshold is higher than the other two as is shown in fig. 1. For example, the spectrum of CuO 8982 eV excitation is already severely deformed from the Ku doublet, while in those of Cu and Cu20 the distortion is still slight. In the resonant or near-resonant condition, two sharp peaks are always observed and the energy shifts of these peaks from the excitation energy correspond to L111 or L11 absorption energy. In the off-resonant case, where the exitation energy is below about 20 eV from the absorption edge, however, the peaks be- come vague and now the edge becomes sharp and well defined, and the energy difference between the exciting line and the edge roughly corresponds to L111 absorption energy. Discussion The spectrum of copper metal obtained here is not the same as those reported earlier [7,9]. As a whole, the spectrum here is much sharper. The intensity falls to practically zero beyond 1000 eV from the edge as is shown in figs. 2 4, while in the previous one a long trailing tail extending well over 1000 eV has been ob- served. The difference can be attributed to the ex- perimental conditions; the width of the exciting light is 2 eV and the resolution of the analyzer is 6 eV in this experiment, while those of the previous work are over 20 eV and about 200 eV, respectively. Different Raman spectra are obtained with Cu, Cu20, and CuO. This indicates that the X-ray Ra- man scattering may be used to investigate electronic structure of materials. At present, however, the im- plication of the spectra is not apparent. Even though the resolution of the present system is good enough for the observation of the EXAFS-like oscillation, no such feature was observed. In the previous reports X-ray Raman scattering from copper has been attributed to originate from second-order perturbation by the pA term of eq. (1) from a prominent resonance enhancement [7 li]. It is also supported by the fact that the scattering is observed even when the polarization vector of the incident light is perpendicular to that of the scat- tered light. When compared with figs. 2 4, the agreement between the observed and the calculated spectra is remarkable in the pre- resonance region, especially for Cu metal and Cu20. This is a clear evidence that the scattering process is described by eq. (3). When the energy difference be- tween the exciting light and the absorption threshold exceeds about 20 eV, the observed spectra depend on the compound and the simple calculation above fails to reproduce the observed one. Therefore more ac- curate excited state wavefunctions which reflect the electronic state of the material should be used in the off-resonant case. With the advent of tunable lasen the transition from resonance Raman scattering to resonance flu- orescence in the optical region attracted much at- tention and still is under current investigation. For example, Hong and Jacobsen observed a change of Raman spectrum from pyrazine by approaching the resonant condition [18], and very recently Harmon and Asher studied emission from benzene by excit- ing around a vibronic band [19]. These are just two of many. In the case of optical Raman spectra of molecules, however, the states 1g>, Ii>, and If> must be de- scribed by complete rovibronic wavefunctions which depend on both electronic and nuclear coordinates (see refs. [18 20], and references therein). A va- riety of approximations and various expansions are employed to evaluate the integrals,, after which the basic physical meanings often become obscured. In addition, the existence of a large number of rovi- bronic levels of molecules in the ground as well as in excited states makes a clearcut experiment difficult. In one of the most illuminating papers concerning the mechanism of resonance Raman scattering, gas phase iodine was studied by Rousseau and Williams [20].
